bestBHT.bht: And now ye know that which hindereth. That which keeps him back, that he may not be revealed before his appointed season. The power that has restrained the man of sin from his full and final development is the moral and conservative influence of political states. Romanism, as a forerunner of Antichrist, was thus kept in check by the Roman emperor until the Roman bishop raised himself to sole empire above the secular power. The removal of the withholding power will be when the civil polity yields to prevalent godless 'lawlessness' with 'the lawless one' as its embodiment.

Henry Alford: And now (not temporal, but as 'seeing that this is so,'—in 1 Cor. xiii. 13,—'now' in our argument) ye know that which hindereth.
that which keeps him back, that he may not be revealed before his.
he may be revealed in his own time.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: The power that has restrained the man of sin from his full and final development, is the moral and conservative influence of political states.
Romanism, as a forerunner of Antichrist, was thus kept in check by the Roman emperor...until the Roman bishop...raised himself...to sole empire above the secular power.
The removal of the withholding power will be when the civil polity...shall...yield to the prevalent godless 'lawlessness' with 'the lawless one' as its embodiment.
Albert Barnes: The restraining power of anything controlled by an individual, or of any government, or the restraining power of God, would meet all that the phrase implies.

The supposition that there was even then a tendency to concentrate all ecclesiastical power at Rome, and that while the civil authority remained there it would not suffer ecclesiastical power to grow to the exorbitant height which it ultimately reached, will meet all that is implied in the language.

There was then a providential arrangement by which this growth of wickedness should be checked and restrained, until the new religion should take deep root in the earth, and its perpetuity should be secured.
Marvin Vincent: The verb means to hold fast, as Luke 8:15 : to hold back, as Luke 4:42. See on Romans 1:18."
He refers to some power which hinders the revelation of the man of sin or Antichrist.
John Calvin: There can be no doubt that the Thessalonians had heard from Paul’s mouth as to this impediment, of whatever sort it was, for he recalls to their remembrance what he had previously taught in their presence.

I seem at least to hear Paul discoursing as to the universal call of the Gentiles — that the grace of God must be offered to all — that Christ must enlighten the whole world by his gospel, in order that the impiety of men might be the more fully attested and demonstrated.
This, therefore, was the delay, until the career of the gospel should be completed, because a gracious invitation to salvation was first in order.
Philip Schaff: If we turn to our Lord’s discourse, the only thing to which such power is ascribed is the purpose of God that the Gospel should first be preached for a witness unto all nations, before the end come.

This interpretation might therefore appeal to the history of the world before the flood, in which God for a time kept down the wickedness, but when the time for judgment came pronounced the final word, ‘My Spirit shall not always strive with man.’

The interpretation which most modern writers agree in accepting is that which understands ‘that which withholdeth’ to be ‘the restraining power of well-ordered human rule, the principles of legality as opposed to those of lawlessness, of which the Roman Empire was the then embodiment and manifestation.’
Archibald T. Robertson: That which restrains. 'This impersonal principle or power is capable also of manifesting itself under a personal form' (Milligan)."
He is Satan's messiah, an infernal caricature of the true Messiah" (Moffatt).
In his own season. Note αυτου (his), not εαυτου (his own), revealed in his time, in the time set him by God.
John Gill: And now ye know what withholdeth... by which is meant not the Apostle Paul... nor the preaching of the Gospel... nor the Spirit of God... nor the general defection... nor is the decree of God meant... but by that which withheld, let or hindered the open appearance of antichrist, were the Roman empire and emperors.

The reason why the apostle expresses this not in plain words, but in an obscure manner, and with so much caution, was, that he might not offend the Roman emperors, and provoke them to a severe persecution.
The word here used, which is rendered 'withholdeth', or 'letteth', as in the next verse, signifies a ruler or governor, and answers to the Hebrew word 'to keep back, or restrain'.
John Wesley: And now ye know...That which restraineth...
The power of the Roman emperors.
His appointed season, and not before.

bhtAttempts.bht: And now (not temporal, but as 'seeing that this is so,'—in 1 Cor. xiii. 13,—'now' in our argument) ye know that which hindereth. That which keeps him back, that he may not be revealed before his appointed season. The power that has restrained the man of sin from his full and final development, is the moral and conservative influence of political states. Romanism, as a forerunner of Antichrist, was thus kept in check by the Roman emperor... until the Roman bishop... raised himself... to sole empire above the secular power. The removal of the withholding power will be when the civil polity... shall... yield to the prevalent godless 'lawlessness' with 'the lawless one' as its embodiment. He is Satan's messiah, an infernal caricature of the true Messiah, revealed in his own time, in the time set him by God. The restraining power of anything controlled by an individual, or of any government, would meet all that the phrase implies.

And now ye know that which hindereth. That which restrains and keeps back the revelation of the man of sin until his appointed season. The power that has restrained the false Messiah from his full development is the moral and conservative influence of political states. Romanism, as a forerunner of Antichrist, was thus kept in check by the Roman emperor until the Roman bishop raised himself to sole empire above the secular power. The removal of the withholding power will happen when civil polity yields to prevalent godless lawlessness.
